dt.un: used to emphasize a minimal amount I hardly knew her almost new — hardly a scratch on it
used to soften a negative you can't hardly tell who anyone is G. B. Shaw

def.dt: :certainly not that news is hardly surprising

entry.pt: Hardly in sense 5 is used sometimes with not for emphasis just another day at the office? Not hardly. In sense 4b with a negative verb (as can't, wouldn't, didn't) it does not make a double negative but softens the negative. In “you can't hardly find a red one,” the sense is that you can find a red one, but only with difficulty; in “you can't find a red one,” the sense is that red ones are simply not available. Use of hardly with a negative verb is a speech form; it is most commonly heard in Southern and Midland speech areas. In other speech areas and in all discursive prose, hardly is normally used with a positive you can hardly find a red one.
